docs.lead_paragraph: WHERE the music calls them, the musicians go. They travel miles to play gigs, work day jobs to support their passion, give years of their lives to the goals of making music that will be heard by more than a handful of people. For some, the big break eventually happens. One of the lucky ones this year is Andy Korn, 36, a drummer who grew up here, lives in an apartment in New Rochelle and returns to the basement of his father's Scarsdale house to practice. Another is Danny Obadiah, 36, a keyboard player and composer from Pelham who, with Mr. Korn, is the founder of the jazz band Aftertouch. Mr. Obadiah and the other band members also practice in the Korn family house -- the drum set, other instruments and sound equipment are too big and loud for most apartments. Since 1991, Mr. Korn and Mr. Obadiah have been analyzing, perfecting, refining and redefining the sound; now, six years later, their first album is about to be released.

headline.main: Band Follows the Beat to a Big Break

docs.abstract: Article on Aftertouch, band from Scarsdale, NY, made up of drummer Andy Korn, keyboardist Danny Obadiah, guitarists Andy Abel and Chulo Gatewood and saxophonist David Mann; photos (M)
docs.snippet: WHERE the music calls them, the musicians go. They travel miles to play gigs, work day jobs to support their passion, give years of their lives to the goals of making music that will be heard by more than a handful of people. For some, the big break...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You discuss employer health care plans in ''Workers Getting Greater Freedom in Health Plans'' (front page, Aug. 21). But as you have reported before, nearly half of the working poor have no insurance. Given the magnitude of this problem, it is tragic that Congress missed two opportunities to address it.

headline.kicker: Don't Tinker Just When Health Care Is Working

docs.abstract: Letter from Kenneth S Abramowitz says Congress missed two opportunities to address problem of working poor, nearly half of whom lack health insurance (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    You discuss employer health care plans in ''Workers Getting Greater Freedom in Health Plans'' (front page, Aug. 21). But as you have reported before, nearly half of the working poor have no insurance. Given the magnitude of this...

docs.lead_paragraph: One late spring day last year, several trucks rolled away from the Hudson Foods processing plant in this small city in the heart of the nation's beef belt. They were loaded with beef patties destined to be turned into Whoppers at Burger King restaurants in the Midwest. But after the trucks were well on the road, Hudson Foods made an unsettling discovery. It had shipped the meat before getting the results of the bacterial tests that Burger King requires, said Mark A. Giresi, senior vice president at Burger King. When the results came back, they showed that some of the beef had staphylococcus bacteria, which can cause vomiting and diarrhea.

headline.main: The Tangled Trail That Led to a Beef Recall

docs.abstract: Tangled trail that led to recall of tainted beef packaged by Hudson Foods highlights problems within beef industry, and says as much about competitive and sensitive nature of industry as about specific quality of production at single meat processor; absence of specific Federal regulations has left many practices within industry determined by dictates of efficiency or marketplace; myriad companies are usually involved in progression of meat from ranch to slaughterhouse to processing plant to customer, so that tracing of problems are often difficult; Federal investigators say even though Hudson plant in Columbus, Neb, is one of most modern in industry and is clean and generally well run, some of its practices are worrisome; cite poor recordkeeping and mixing of leftover meat into next day's production; decision by Burger King, company's largest customer, to stop buying its meat noted; photos (M)
docs.snippet: One late spring day last year, several trucks rolled away from the Hudson Foods processing plant in this small city in the heart of the nation's beef belt. They were loaded with beef patties destined to be turned into Whoppers at Burger King...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Workers Getting Greater Freedom in Health Plans'' (front page, Aug. 17) says traditional fee-for-service, or indemnity, plans are more expensive than managed care or point-of-service plans. This is only true when the indemnity policy carries a low deductible. When employers offer the option of a high-deductible indemnity policy, the savings can be substantial.

headline.kicker: Don't Tinker Just When Health Care Is Working

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr David T Springer says savings are substantial when employers offer option of high-deductible fee-for-service, or indemnity, plan (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: DICK BELCHER, a bank president in a small Indiana town, cannot recall when the economy was better. At his bank, delinquencies are virtually nonexistent and business is steady. While a strong economy brings many good things to small businesses like his, it also creates a problem: Where do you find enough qualified employees?

headline.main: For Many Small Businesses, The Labor Pool Is Shallow

docs.abstract: Small businesses are having trouble attracting qualified workers, particularly in rural communities with small labor pools; owners report raising wages or benefits to attract workers, becoming more flexible with work schedules and advertising jobs over much wider areas; table; photo (M)
docs.snippet: DICK BELCHER, a bank president in a small Indiana town, cannot recall when the economy was better. At his bank, delinquencies are virtually nonexistent and business is steady.    While a strong economy brings many good things to small businesses like...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE stock market's recent slump -- and its wild volatility last week -- are shuffling the leader boards for stocks and mutual funds. The well-known multinational stocks that pulled the market higher all year, like General Electric and Exxon, have been outpaced by smaller companies from Ethan Allan furniture to Pool Energy Services. And the once-popular consumer stocks like Coca-Cola, Gillette and Procter & Gamble have lagged badly, even as stocks that tend to track the overall economy, the ones like Caterpillar and Alcoa that Wall Street calls cyclicals, have more than held their own.

headline.main: Laggards Become Leaders As Small Stocks Revive
headline.kicker: INVESTING IT/MUTUAL FUNDS -- THE MARKETS: Navigating Choppy Waters

docs.abstract: Stocks of smaller companies and cyclical stocks, which failed to keep pace earlier in year with gains posted by big multinational and consumer products stocks, are new market leaders; gains come in face of recent market slump and last week's wild volatility; experts say changes have been driven by concerns about corporate earnings that underpin bull market; turnabout has lifted some depressed diversified domestic mutual funds, particularly funds that invest in smallest stocks; graph; table; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: THE stock market's recent slump -- and its wild volatility last week -- are shuffling the leader boards for stocks and mutual funds.    The well-known multinational stocks that pulled the market higher all year, like General Electric and Exxon, have...

docs.lead_paragraph: The day the child was born, to a woman who might have briefly loved her, a small-town doctor in northern Georgia passed her through the back door of his office to a tire maker and his wife from Akron, Ohio, who wanted a baby badly enough to buy one. She had dark brown hair and emerald eyes, and cost $1,000 on Jan. 15, 1965. The doctor threw in a fake birth certificate that listed the buyers as birth parents, erasing the real mother from the child's past.

headline.main: Town Secret Is Uncovered In Birth Quest

docs.abstract: Jane Blasio's search for her birth mother in McCaysville, Ga, brings to light the black-market sale of as many as 200 babies delivered there by the late Dr Thomas Jugarthy Hicks between 1951 and 1965; Hicks performed abortions, which were illegal at the time, in addition to caring for miners, farmers and townspeople, and he persuaded some young women who came to him for abortions to carry their babies to full term; sold newborns to people who wanted a baby with no questions asked, sometimes requiring them to go through an odd charade of childbirth; about 50 'Hicks babies' and seven mothers have come forward so far, but no positive matches between parents and children have been made; photos of Blasio, Hicks and Judge Linda Davis, who helped Blasio unearth the story (M)
docs.snippet: The day the child was born, to a woman who might have briefly loved her, a small-town doctor in northern Georgia passed her through the back door of his office to a tire maker and his wife from Akron, Ohio, who wanted a baby badly enough to buy one. ...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Aug. 15 front-page article on the cutoff of disability checks to 95,180 children fails to mention that those determined to be disabled and eligible for Supplemental Security Income are automatically eligible for Medicaid. As you say, children must also be from low-income families for S.S.I. Therefore, it is likely that many of these children were previously uninsured. Eligibility for Medicaid, which usually covers more comprehensive services for these children than private health insurance, is frequently more valuable than S.S.I. In recognition of this, Congress determined that children losing S.S.I. eligibility would retain Medicaid eligibility.

headline.main: Quick Fix Ignores Future Disabled Children

docs.abstract: Letter from Kathleen A Maloy says Aug 15 article on cutoff of disability checks to disabled children fails to mention that those determined to be disabled are automatically eligible for Medicaid; says real problem is for future uninsured poor children who will not qualify for SSI under more rigorous standards (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Your Aug. 15 front-page article on the cutoff of disability checks to 95,180 children fails to mention that those determined to be disabled and eligible for Supplemental Security Income are automatically eligible for Medicaid. As...

docs.lead_paragraph: A hospital efficiency expert testified in Federal court today that the merger of two of Long Island's largest hospital networks, Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Health Systems, would lead to savings of $92 million a year in administrative expenses in five years and $78 million in building and other capital costs. The witness, Robert N. Davis, a financial analyst with the accounting firm of Ernst & Young, said the savings would help hold down hospital rates and enable the merged nonprofit hospital network to continue its teaching, medical research and caring for the poor.

headline.main: U.S. and Two Hospitals Battle Over Merger on Long Island

docs.abstract: Ernst & Young financial analyst Robert N Davis testifies in Federal court that merger of Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Health Systems would lead to savings of $92 million a year in administrative expenses in five years and $78 million in building and other capital costs; testimony contradicts Justice Dept's contention that merger would lead to higher hospital rates and inhibit development of competing hospital systems (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have obtained evidence that some hospitals owned by the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation may have improperly billed the Government for costs related to a series of programs operated by the health care giant to attract the elderly as patients. Such programs have long been a critical component of the company's competitive strategy, and have been used at Columbia hospitals to expand their outreach to the elderly. Senior citizens are among the most lucrative population segment in the health care market, since they combine both a great need for medical services and significant levels of insurance through Medicare and private health programs.

headline.main: U.S. Looks at Columbia/HCA Elderly Programs

docs.abstract: Federal prosecutors have obtained evidence that some hospitals owned by Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp may have improperly billed Government for costs related to series of programs operated by Columbia/HCA to attract elderly as patients; such programs have long been critical component of company's competitive strategy, and have been used at Columbia hospitals to expand their outreach to elderly (L)
